title: Rock Your Breast Cancer Hair
author: Emily L Foley

content: Chemo is a key part of treatment for many types of cancer . It can help save your life.

But it does have side effects, including hair loss and hair thinning, which typically starts about 2-4 weeks after you start chemo . How you decide to manage those changes is personal. Some extra TLC and gentle styling will come in handy.

sections.heading: Start With Healthy Hair
content: “As soon as you're diagnosed, stop harsh styling practices,” says Jerilynn Stephens, a Los Angeles-based hair stylist. That includes bleaching, coloring, braids, and weaves, as well as using high-heat tools like blow-dryers, or curling or straightening irons,
L.A. hair stylist Jerilynn Stephens has worked on the set of the TV show The Voice for most of its many seasons.
Strong hair from the get-go has a better fighting chance when treatment begins, Stephens says. She’s not just speaking as a professional. She went through ovarian cancer chemo in 2021.

Some people try cold caps, or scalp cooling, to try to prevent or reduce chemo-related hair loss. The idea is that the cold temperature restricts blood flow , which cuts down on how much chemo gets to the hair follicle. The FDA has approved some automated devices for this purpose. There are also frozen gel caps that cost less but  aren’t regulated by the FDA. These products may help some people, but not everyone – and you may still lose some hair, though less than without them. Talk with your doctor before you start scalp cooling.

sections.heading: Get a Good Cut
content: A smart, shorter new 'do does more than give you a fresh look. It can help hide thinning hair, unlike long locks, where loss is more obvious.
Style gently:
Baby your scalp . Even as you try to preserve your hair, chemotherapy dries out your scalp. Stephens suggests using an organic body oil to moisturize it.
Protect it, too, with sunscreen. You may also want a hat, scarf, or wig for warmth.
Sometimes, shaving your head after it begins to fall out is the most emotionally powerful thing you can do.
bullets: If you pull it up, use scrunchies instead of hair elastics. Opt for a low bun instead of a high topknot, which holds your hair too tightly.
Wash your hair less: only when you must, and with a super-gentle shampoo.
Switch to a super-soft pillowcase. Satin or silk are smoother than cotton, taking it easier on your hair.

sections.heading: Shaved Is a Style, Too
content: “Sometimes, shaving your head after it begins to fall out is the most emotionally powerful thing you can do because it takes back the power for yourself and can prevent the trauma of the unexpected,” Stephens says.

A friend who'd gone through cancer suggested Stephens shave her head to show she was bigger than the treatment. Her son and her family joined her. “It was powerful for my family … for us to do that together.”

sections.heading: When Your Hair Grows Back
content: After chemo, your hair may grow differently than what you had before.
For instance, it may grow in more like a fine down than the hair you had before.

“As it begins to grow more, it's important to get frequent tiny trims to take off those fuzzy ends, so more of the 'real' hair can show,” Stephens says. “However, even as that initial baby hair is trimmed off, what's left isn't always what you started with.”
Jerilynn Stephens marks her fourth chemo treatment.
Your post-cancer hair might be darker, much lighter, or a different texture. Your curly hair might have gone straight, or from thin to thick, or vice versa.

content: “The key is to embrace the fact that you have hair once again, and learn how to style the new texture that you are receiving,” Stephens says.
Your new hair is fragile. So be gentle. No harsh brushing or coloring, bleaching, or perming, as the new hair is fragile. Choose mild shampoo, conditioner, and other hair products, too.

sections.heading: Hair Extensions After Cancer
content: Lacy West of Laced Hair Extensions in Utah lost most of her hair in treatment for a brain tumor.
Once your hair has grown back in, wearing hair extensions is an option until your own hair has grown to the length and thickness you want.

“Your hair should be at least 4 inches long before you think about extensions,” says Lacy West of Laced Hair Extensions in Salt Lake City, Utah. She lost about 75% of her hair during treatment for an inoperable brain tumor.
Tape-ins are typically the best type of extensions to use on post-chemo hair, since clip-ins can show in shorter hair, West says.

meta_description: Hair loss and regrowth are challenging side effects of cancer treatment. Learn how healthy habits and smart styling can make a big difference.
